Award.AbstractNarration:
Brain plasticity, the adaptability of the nervous system in response to experience, is a modulatory process leading to long-lasting structural and functional changes. Plasticity has been thought to characterize neurons primarily. Preliminary data suggest that glia, cells thought to provide nutritive support for neurons, undergo a new, potentially fundamental form of plasticity: diurnal and light-stimulated morphological dynamics in the central circadian clock, the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN). This concept is novel and has not been effectively explored. Knowledge of the patterns and regulators of SCN glial plasticity over the daily cycle will contribute significant new insights on glial cellular dynamics in the brain, an emergent property of an understudied area. Goals of educational and outreach components are to develop and validate effective cross-disciplinary instructional modules involving neuroscience, imaging, and three-dimensional analytic techniques. Emphasis will be on engaging women and groups underrepresented in neuroscience research. Outcomes will include a series of educational materials, presentations, and publications for use with K-12 educators and students and the general public aimed at increasing interest and awareness of recent research findings. This will enhance scientific literacy.

The scientific issues will be addressed using confocal microscopy coupled with computer-based analysis of glial structural complexity and spatial organization in the rat SCN. This study will advance understanding of diurnal modulation of glial plasticity in two ways: 1) providing an unbiased, high-resolution three-dimensional assessment of diurnal patterns of SCN glial plasticity, and 2) generating new insights on signals that alter glial structure and thereby dynamic cell-cell relationships. Assessment of efficacy of the educational and outreach components will be made in partnership with Prof. Lizanne DeStefano, Director of the Illinois STEM Education Initiative and an expert in design and evaluation of innovative STEM education programs. They will employ a robust goal-based evaluation to validate, document, and disseminate this model through publication and presentation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Within all cells are self-sustained, near-24-hour circadian clocks that coordinate body systems and synchronize the internal processes with daily changes in light on Earth. The synchronization of these rhythms is controlled in a region of the brain called the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN), which is the body’s master timekeeper. It is composed of both neural cells and a type of brain cell, glia, once believed to provide primarily structural support to neurons. Glial cells are the focus of our research under this award. Glia include star-shaped astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and microglia, which all play a role in regulating an organism’s circadian rhythms. We now know that, in addition to roles in structural support, dynamic changes in the shape of glial cells across the day-night cycle can alter neuronal interrelationships and excitability. Retraction of glial processes in response to stressors increases neuron-to-neuron contacts, enhancing communication and synchronization. Under this NSF award, we have made important discoveries related to changes in glial cells and their role in SCN physiology, which, in turn, is modulated by differential release of molecules identified as neuropeptides. Such neuropeptides communicate time-of-day-specific light signals.

   Under this award, we have added to our knowledge of diurnal astrocyte and neuron remodeling in the SCN and also in the hippocampus and in the effect of redox state on circadian rhythms. Beyond the SCN, circadian oscillations are seen in cells of other brain regions, such as the hippocampus, which is critical to learning and memory formation, and even in cellular processes such as metabolism. Recent work in our laboratory under this protocol has found a circadian pattern of oscillation in redox state within the SCN and hippocampus. Both neuronal membrane excitability and redox state exhibit oscillations in rat hippocampal CA1 pyramidal neurons around the circadian cycle. Both patterns are ~180° out-of-phase with those reported previously in the SCN neurons. This is provocative evidence indicating a new type of coupling between cellular metabolism and the transcription-translation oscillation of clock genes, which we hope to continue investigating using patch-clamp electrophysiology and an adeno-associated viral vector to trace inputs and outputs in the functional circuitry of the hippocampus relative to time of day.

Under this protocol, we have shown that the network of neurons and glial cells comprising the SCN and hippocampus and their interactions change morphologically and functionally between day and night in predictable ways. They are more complex, highly dynamic, and heterogeneous than previously understood. Results of many of these experiments have been presented at professional meetings and published. Studies supported by this award have led to a Beckman Graduate Fellowship, a proposal for future studies, 5 publications in peer-reviewed journals, and over 30 abstracts for presentations at scientific meetings.  

   Broader impacts of this award relate to educational, training, and professional development of future scientists and the community, especially under-represented minority students and, notably, across multiple scientific disciplines. I have mentored trainees on an NSF Science & Technology Center grant, involving MIT, Illinois, and Georgia Tech together with 3 minority-serving institutions, and 16 others, and on a total of 5 training grants. Directly related to this NSF IOS award, the weekly seminar course, Current Topics in Neurons and Glia, has been taught each spring and fall semester for the past 5 ½ years.

   Undergraduates and women, including many engineering majors, are actively integrated in our training programs and our research. Our Miniature Brain Machinery NSF-funded NRT training program enrolled 12 trainees in its first year, 75% of which are women, under-represented minorities, veterans, and/or students who are the first in their families to attend college! Our research and educational goals provided opportunities for training and professional development for undergraduates and graduate students in ways that 1) enhance their personal and professional development, and 2) enable them to interact across disciplines. These experiences included reading and interpreting primary scientific literature, conducting bench research, engaging the broad scientific community with poster and oral presentations, learning how to draft hypotheses and specific aims, as well as writing research papers. Over the course of this grant, these research opportunities have directly affected 1 high school student, 10 undergraduates (7 via REU grants in Biomedical Imaging and EBICS), 6 graduate students, a technical research specialist, and a senior scientist. Ten of these individuals are women, 1 is an Iraqi war veteran, and at least seven are under-represented minorities (URMs). Our diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students developed new research and analytical skills and knowledge as a consequence of their work on this project. Key areas of growth are in understanding the neurobiology of astrocytes, cellular dynamics, cutting-edge imaging technologies, methods for analyzing cellular structure and animal behavior, evaluating the effect of light-induced stimulation of the optic nerve on astrocyte remodeling within the SCN, and in presenting their research findings to the broader community.
